article_title: Nurses throwing money and support into Sanders’ campaign
article_text:
Nurses throwing money and support into Sanders’ campaign

Photo: Jacquelyn Martin, STF / Associated Press Listening journalists and television cameras are reflected in the...

WASHINGTON — With Hillary Clinton’s Texas experience and powerful endgame before the March 1 primary, it might seem rash for any segment of Bernie Sanders’ backers to profess confidence that the Vermont senator will fare well in the Lone Star State.

article_metadata.description: WASHINGTON — With Hillary Clinton’s Texas experience and powerful endgame before the March 1 primary, it might seem rash for any segment of Bernie Sanders’ backers to profess confidence that the Vermont senator will fare well in the Lone Star State.  Sanders decries Super PACs and big-money donors, but the National Nurses Union has spent $1.7 million and counting on his behalf, says the Sunlight Foundation, which advocates transparency in politics.  Castro, Rep. Luis Gutierrez, D-Ill., and Dolores Huerta, co-founder of the United Farm Workers, issued a statement through Clinton asserting that Sanders was “on the wrong side of the immigration debate” by voting against an immigration reform bill in 2007.  For Sanders, a trove of 252 Texas delegates — many of which will be apportioned based on the March 1 vote — is appealing, and the campaign has scoffed at the notion that Clinton, polling well in many states, can deliver mortal damage to Sanders’ effort in Texas.  The unionized nurses contend they understand America’s health system as well as anyone, and they back Sanders because of his embrace of a single-payer health care system, not in spite of it.  Sanders’ support of single-payer — in which government oversees health insurance rather than private insurers — has proved challenging for Clinton to answer.  “Whether it’s legalization of recreational activities, health care for everyone, larger taxes on business, those are the ideas that appeal to people of college age, and people on into their 30s,” he said.
article_metadata.author.name: By Bill Lambrecht, Washington Bureau
